Description.val:
The MQ-8 Fire Scout Unmanned Air System provides real-time Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) data to tactical users without the use of manned aircraft or reliance on limited joint theater or national assets. This line item funds improvements through engineering change orders, correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety. This includes items such as modernization, modification and retrofit of air vehicle, avionics, payloads/mission systems and Mission Control Systems (MCS) (also referred to as Ground Control Stations) components and systems. The program will procure a total of 68 air vehicles (30 MQ-8Bs (7 lost to attrition) and 38 MQ-8Cs) to support Fleet requirements. Current inventory is twenty-three (23) MQ-8B and twenty-eight (28) MQ-8C air vehicles. Twenty-three (23) MQ-8B Fire Scout systems are in service, of which twenty-two (22) are available for fleet use. Twenty-eight (28) MQ-8C Fire Scouts are in service with nine (9) additional MQ-8Cs under contract. Twenty-two (22) MQ-8Cs are located at the Fleet Contractor Field Team (CFT) supported storage and maintenance facility at Naval Base Ventura County (NBVC) Pt. Mugu, CA.  Two (2) MQ-8B and six (6) MQ-8C Fire Scouts are at Webster Field, MD. These Operational, Safety and Improvement Programs align to the MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability in 2014 and MQ-8C deliveries that commenced in 2015. 

The MQ-8 Fire Scout system includes air vehicle(s), payloads (e.g., electro-optical/infra-red/laser designator-range finder, Automated Information System (AIS), voice communications relay, Radar, Weapons and other specialty payloads), MCS (with Tactical Control System and Tactical Common Data Link integrated for interoperability), Unmanned Air Vehicle Common Automatic Recovery System (UCARS) for automatic launch and recovery, training systems, associated spares, and support equipment.  The quantities and schedules for MCS and UCARS components are based on host ship requirements, while quantities and schedules for air vehicle components are based on operational deployment plans.  The MQ-8 system supports Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) and/or suitably-equipped air capable ship ISR collection for Navy and urgent operational requirements.  Designated service life and average service life remaining are currently being computed via a fatigue life evaluation.

Justification.val: FY21 funds improvements via engineering change orders, for correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety. This includes correction of deficiencies found during operational use and deployments, improvements for maintainability and reliability, safety corrections, Radar/other special payloads, Mission Control System (MCS), and emerging requirements and retrofit of capabilities procured post air vehicle delivery.  Budget reflects MQ-8Cs, procurements starting in FY12, being transitioned to Fleet service.

ModificationTitle.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiencies and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Name.@footnote: ILS: cost will vary as Engineering Change Proposal requirements change.

Training Equipment: supports update of , but not limited to, Avionics Maintenance Trainer (AMT) and Combined Maintenance Trainer (CMT). AMT and CMT equipment along with other training equipment is required to support training event on both East and West coast locations. Additionally, training equipment is procured as required to support changes in air vehicle configuration.

Description.val:
The Correction of Deficiencies (COD) Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) provides resources to correct MQ-8 Air Vehicle deficiencies resulting from readiness, obsolescence, safety and Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) issues. It also provides for Pre-Planned Product Improvement (P3I) efforts that will improve and modernize system performance, reliability, and maintainability of sensors, avionics, and airframe components to support Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) collection for both Navy and urgent operational requirements. In order to meet emerging deficiencies in the MQ-8B and MQ-8C aircraft, integrated systems and trainers must be modified when critical corrections / changes are identified. Funds will be used to incorporate Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) and implement those changes to sustain and improve operations. Funding supports the upgrade of the communication radio set with the ARC-210 1939A variant, which supports crypto compatibility required by FY21.

Modifications for the MQ-8 aircraft include, but are not limited to:  MQ-8B payloads, Video Oriented Transceiver for Exchange of Information (VORTEX) relocation, hot weather modifications, blades, engines, control rods, heavy gauge wiring, engine accelerometers, optical tracker cable, navigation lights, corrosion prevention, light weight doors, Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Common Automated Recovery System (UCARS), lithium ion battery, windscreen, airframe structure, ARC-210 radios, Tactical Common Data Link (TCDL), shipboard interface system, common avionics, software, cyber security, network interfaces, processor upgrades, System Integration Lab (SIL) and Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) enhancements, Windows 10 transition, maintenance device updates, and other related systems. 

The FY21 budget focus includes Redundancy Upgrade for UCARS, the top safety priority for the MQ-8, and the Processor Upgrade, an obsolescence issue.  

This OSIP provides funds to support modifications to address safety and readiness issues and the establishment of Organic Depot Capability for Core Repairables. Modifications will be depot-level performed by Fleet Readiness Centers, contractor artisans, contractor field modification teams, and/or operational-level performed by organic support.  Coincident with the MQ-8B deployment on the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) class, a top ten safety issue list was developed during the program's System Safety Working Group. As solutions become available, aircraft modifications will be implemented to address critical safety issues. Identified issues include icing detection/avoidance, ground handling, airspace awareness, Global Positioning System vulnerabilities, and cyber security.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability (IOC) occurred in FY14. The MQ-8B has deployed since FY10 to support Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need, and is embarked aboard the LCS classes of ships as part of the Surface Warfare Mission Package.  The MQ-8B will deploy aboard the LCS classes of ships as part of Mine Counter-Measures (MCM) missions beginning in FY19.

Description.val:
The Mission Control System (MCS) Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) addresses modifications to MCS for hardware.  Funding supports the External Communications (EXCOMM) rack and the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Common Automatic Recovery System (UCARS) obsolete components which require replacement.  Non-recurring engineering has been completed to support production.  This effort procures the kits required and funds the retrofit of shipboard MD-4 MCS equipment onboard Littoral Combat Ships (LCS), other suitably equipped air-capable ships, and shore-based MD-4B MCS equipment installed at fleet locations.  Funding supports the upgrade of the communication radio set with the ARC-210 1939A variant, which supports crypto compatibility required by FY21. Additionally, the radio OEM (Rockwell Collins) completes production and procurement of the ARC-210 1939A variant in FY21.  

This budget accelerates MCS upgrades to reduce cyber security vulnerabilities, reduces obsolescence, and supports fleet requirements.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability (IOC) occurred in FY14.  The MQ-8B has deployed since FY10 to support Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need, and is preparing to embark on multiple operational deployments aboard the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) class as part of the Surface Warfare Mission Package.  

MCS and UCARS requirements were aligned from OSIP 021-14 to OSIP 009-17 in FY 2017 budget request.

Name.@footnote: Training Equip.: Increase in funding from FY22 to FY23 supports the initial procurement support of Link-16 training equipment.

MQ-8C Radar A Kits: Radar A-Kit and B-kit procurements for FY21-FY24 and Radar installations for FY22-FY25 were reduced due to the offset for MQ-8B sundown.  The offset significantly slows Radar installations and delivery of Radar installed MQ-8Cs to the Fleet and delays completion of Radar modifications on MQ-8C by over two years. The six (6) Radar installations in FY22 include installation of A-kits procured in both FY20 Four (4) and FY21 Two (2).  This is required because the prior year A-kit procurement in FY17 could not be installed until FY19 due to delays encountered in system level qualification of the A kit (specifically the Mission Processor Unit).  Installs of FY18 and FY19 A kits also are planned to be installed with the same one year delay due the schedule of the Prime A kit procurement contract (in negotiation).  FY22 is the first opportunity to correct the installation delay and catch-up to the procurement schedule.

MQ-8C Radar Upgrade II B Kits: Procurements for FY20, FY21, and FY22 are covered by a current, already negotiated IDIQ contract.  This contract includes negotiated IDIQ pricing and may incur additional costs depending on the exchange rate at the time of exercising the order.
Name.val: 2.1.1) MQ-8C Radar Upgrade II B Kits - Organic

MQ-8C Link-16

Description.val:
The MQ-8 Payloads Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) addresses modifications to the MQ-8 Fire Scout System which adds new payloads, such as Radar and Link-16, and adds capability and reliability improvements to existing payloads.  

The Radar payload includes the integration of a competitively-selected non-developmental item Radar with the air vehicle, Minotaur data correlation and resource management software and hardware, and Mission Control Station (MCS). This capability will improve the MQ-8 Fire Scout's performance in support of Surface Warfare (SUW) Mission Module for the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) and urgent operational requirements. Once the hardware and software modifications to the air vehicle and MCS are complete, the MQ-8 Fire Scout Mission System Trainer, Avionics Technicians' Trainer, and Aircraft Mechanics' Trainer will be upgraded to include this capability. Delivered MQ-8C air vehicles will be retrofitted for the upgrades via kits. 

Link-16 payload includes the integration of a Link-16 terminal hardware with the air vehicle, integration of a Link-16 processor hardware with the air vehicle, modification of the Mission Processor Unit (MPU) that hosts Minotaur on the air vehicle, and modification of the Mission Control Station (MCS).  Link-16 Line of Sight (LOS) capability will disseminate sensor track data to other Link-16 participants contributing to the Common Operational Picture and increasing situational awareness.  Additionally, the Link-16 In-Flight Target Update (IFTU) capability will allow for Network Enabled Weapon Targeting (NEW-T) for Over-the-Horizon Targeting (OTH-T).  Minotaur software will be used to correlate sensor data and manage the Link-16 network. Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) for initial Link-16 integration will commence in FY20 for the Link-16 hardware and associated software modification to the MQ-8C air vehicle and MCS. Delivered MQ-8C air vehicles will be retrofitted for the Link-16 upgrades via kits.  

Future integration of payloads include Mine Countermeasures (MCM) mission module on LCS and the Data Mission Payload (DMP). Future payload integration efforts will be considered when integrating current efforts. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS AND MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 
Payload Milestones: A maritime Radar has been competitively selected for integration into the MQ-8C Fire Scout System. Completion of development and integration is anticipated in FY20 with a Follow-on Test and Evaluation
(FOT&E) period starting in 1Q FY21, followed by an Initial Operational Capability (IOC) in 4Q FY21.
